text.headline: Holiday haul, circa 19th century
text.text:
Long before unboxing videos proliferated YouTube, Americans cataloged hauls of Christmas gifts via handwritten letters and diary entries. Take a tour of selected manuscripts from the Newberry's collections to track shifts in giving, from handmade mittens to store-bought toiletries to personal checks. Such changes in consumerism can help expand our understanding of America’s social and cultural history.

media.caption: Letter, Dec. 25, 1860. Everett family papers, Newberry Library

text.headline: Pleasing little socks, Osawatamie, KS, 1860
text.text:
Dear Father and all friends at home;

...I hardly know how to express our feeling of gratitude and comfort and happiness at getting so many nice things from you and our Steuben friends. You could not have sent things so appropriate to our needs and longings if we had sent to tell what to send. Sarah asked Robert when we heard of the box what he wanted to come in the box! 'Bobbie want a little clock, and a knife and a pair of boots.' So you see he was suited exactly. Tell Aunty that the children were very much pleased with their little socks...

Your affectionate children,
John and Sarah Everett

media.caption: Diary entry, Dec. 26, 1869. Julia Newberry diary, Newberry Library

text.headline: A lovely madonna, Brooklyn, NY, 1869
text.text:
Thursday evening last I went to my first dinner party, + never in my life was I so bored... Christmas passed quietly but comfortably, the presents that pleased me most were a real artist's parasol, from mamma, + a lovely Madonna in a carved frame... Then we went to see the performance at St. Albans, with which we were soon disgusted. My appetite is much better, & we made a comfortable dinner, of Green Turtle soup, trout, grouse, & champagne.

media.caption: Letter, Dec. 31, 1870. Everett family papers , Newberry Library

text.headline: A Blue & Gilt match safe, Williamsburg, IA, 1870
text.text:
Dear ones at home;

I wish you a Happy New Year!! Did you have a Merry Christmas & what presents did you all have? I had a plate of candy and a glass toilet set, blue & gilt, consisting of two bottles for cologne & a match safe. They are pretty ornaments for a mantel & will be nice when little Eddie & I get our office!! Won't they Eddie? They now grase the parlor of my landlady...

Yours lovingly,
Mary

media.caption: Letter, Jan. 6, 1871. Everett family papers, Newberry Library

text.headline: A box of paper collars, Williamstown, NY, 1871
text.text:
Dear Aunt Cynthia,

I got a gun, a rooster, a knife, a trumpet, a ball, a bird whistle, a watch, a tin savings bank, on the Christmas tree. I will tell you another time what I got to wear. Aunt Anna and I made 10 pin flats, 6 pin cushions, an ornament for Maggie to put on the tree. I thank you for my nice present that you sent me... Now I will tell you what I got on the tree to wear. A pair of wristlets from Maggie, gloves from Aunt Jane, a box of paper collars from Tommy, two neckties from Anna, a scarf, and a story book and a writing book besides.

Johnnie

media.caption: Diary entry, Dec. 23-26, 1881. Rowley family journals, Newberry Library

text.headline: A rocking chair for unworthy me, Oak Park, IL, 1881
text.text:
Dec. 23: Martha went to Chicago and got Christmas things among which was a willow rocking chair for unworthy me.

Dec. 26: Well Christmas is over and I guess it is a relief to all of us though we had a very good time and have great reason to be thankful that we have all been spared another year and no great calamities have befallen us but there is always so much hubbub and excitement attendant through the holidays that it seem comfortable to have a rest.

media.caption: Letter, Jan. 2, 1899. Everett family papers, Newberry Library

text.headline: That sweet little glove buttoner, Hillsdale, MI, 1899
text.text:
My dear Aunties,

A very happy New Year to you both. I was so very pleased to get that sweet little glove buttoner, now I sha'n't have to borrow Mamma's but can use my own. Thank you so much.

I have had a lovely Christmas any way. We went to Hudson as usual and had our presents Monday afternoon. I stayed until Saturday and then came home to go to the loveliest New Year's party at Mrs. Ammerman's. We had the finest time and the daintiest refreshments. We came away a little before eleven for we thought it too late to stay and watch the old year out.

With a great deal of love,
Anna Louise Sands

media.caption: Letter, Jan. 29, 1899. Everett family papers, Newberry Library

text.headline: A moustache cup & saucer, Kiowa, KS, 1899
text.text:
Dear Aunties:

For Christmas I got a shirt, hat, lantern a pin that you sent me and a nice tie to wear it in. Papa got a hat, a moustache cup & saucer, and a comb from me. Mamma got a double-boiler & a box of nice hair-pins.

Roberts got a whole lot of things a doll, a pair of slippers, a silver napkin-ring, a silver spoon from you, and a lot of other things. When he was sick he got two dollars for taking a tea spoonful of medicine and Mamma gave him a calf but he said that he would rather have the calf be part of Mamma's, and the doctor said he would have his pony brought from his claim in the strip for Roberts to ride.

I remain yours with love,
Howard

media.caption: Letter, Nov. 11, 1930. Emily Elliot Daland papers. Newberry Library

text.headline: A merry check, Brookline, MA, 1930
text.text:
My dear Helen -

...At any rate I rejoice to think you will be given a 'new lease on life' and can journey forward with new hope and courage. Christmas is coming and so I send a Merry one to you both with this check!

Yours ever faithfully,
Emily Daland
